title-group.article-title: Changing the lexicon of ‘Cardiac Rehabilitation’: a progressive step

body.p: The questioning by Ting et al.1 of the use of the term ‘cardiac rehabilitation’ is insightful and timely. Continued use of this term is at odds with evolving modern risk reduction programmes, exemplified by diabetes care. The term ‘rehabilitation’ conveys an intervention from which the patient is ‘rehabilitated’. Rather than a time-limited rehabilitation period, contemporary coronary heart disease (CHD) management seeks to reduce cardiovascular risk via life-long behaviour change and ongoing care. However, revising the macro-label alone fails to recognize the severity and underlying causes of the low use of cardiac rehabilitation.

From the plethora of guidelines and position statements, it is easier to prescribe pharmacotherapy or perform interventional procedures than to encourage participation in a continuing disease management programme such as cardiac rehabilitation; or is it? Ting et al.1 suggest that cardiac rehabilitation is considered less important by mainstream cardiology because patients are unaware of its existence, benefits, and relevance. Whilst true, it also must also be recognized that large numbers of patients who are aware of its existence and benefits still decide not to participate.2,3 Utilization of centre-based cardiac rehabilitation services is strongly influenced by many additional factors, among them the large distance which most patients have to travel to programmes and their sex and age.2,3

In addition to programme labelling, we contend that under-utilization of cardiac rehabilitation is due to poor evidence translation secondary to the complexity of the evidence base and the lengthy timeline in adopting research findings into clinical practice.4 In particular, while evidence supporting more flexible and accessible home and community-based secondary prevention approaches to the management of chronic CHD is compelling5,6 its implementation lags.

Given the strong evidence base, a broad implementation strategy for more accessible and effective services is urgently required. Use of more inclusive labelling such as ‘ongoing prevention’, ‘cardiac risk management programmes’, ‘cardiac secondary prevention’, or other terms1 is a progressive step. Adopting any one of these terms may help cover the gamut of proven secondary prevention strategies.5,6 However, we stress, this must be part of a wider strategy that promotes evidence translation; e.g. use of popular opinion leaders, one-to-one educational sessions on programme benefits, decision support tools, and small group problem based learning.4

Universal, clear and consistent terminology in describing and reporting all types of CHD management programmes are needed in parallel with greater evidence translation if we are to achieve the goal of universal participation. Both a change in lexicon of cardiac rehabilitation coupled with effective evidence-translation strategies are required to successfully address the unfortunate and systematic low use of current services.
